thread.title: Five keys for the Miami Dolphins to defeat the Tennessee Titans
thread.title_full: Five keys for the Miami Dolphins to defeat the Tennessee Titans

title: Five keys for the Miami Dolphins to defeat the Tennessee Titans
text:
Five keys for the Miami Dolphins to defeat the Tennessee Titans Caption Dolphins need to rush for 100 yards for the second time this season Jim Rassol / Sun Sentinel 
Lamar Miller, who is averaging 3.5 yards per attempt, and Jonas Gray need to combine for 20 carries, which should help keep Miami’s offense balanced. The Dolphins would benefit from leaning heavily on the play-action game against Tennessee’s aggressive defensive front, which is anchored by defensive tackle Jurell Casey and pass rusher Derrick Morgan. 
Lamar Miller, who is averaging 3.5 yards per attempt, and Jonas Gray need to combine for 20 carries, which should help keep Miami’s offense balanced. The Dolphins would benefit from leaning heavily on the play-action game against Tennessee’s aggressive defensive front, which is anchored by defensive tackle Jurell Casey and pass rusher Derrick Morgan. (Jim Rassol / Sun Sentinel) Caption The Dolphins must shut down Tennessee's rushing attack Andy Lyons / Getty Images 
Miami must limit the Titans to fewer than 100 yards. The Titans, who average 4.1 yards per rush with Bishop Sankey and Dexter McCluster, account for 118 rushing yards per contest. The Dolphins defense has been allowing 160 rushing yards per game, which ranks the Dolphins dead last at defending the run. 
Miami must limit the Titans to fewer than 100 yards. The Titans, who average 4.1 yards per rush with Bishop Sankey and Dexter McCluster, account for 118 rushing yards per contest. The Dolphins defense has been allowing 160 rushing yards per game, which ranks the Dolphins dead last at defending the run. (Andy Lyons / Getty Images) 
Omar Kelly provides the five areas of greatest importance for the Miami Dolphins as they try to win in Dan Campbell's coaching debut in Tennessee and improve to 2-3: Loading
